field_edited_text.value:
movements and speed, and expand the
public’s knowledge of operational safety
measures.

Some of those recommendations have
included.

1) Initiate a 6 knot speed limit in the
Northwest and Middle Branches to
control the speed of boats. This will
also allow the Baltimore City Police,
Marine Division to issue tickets to

.speeders. The rule went into effect on
June 21st, 1982.

2) Begin an internal City review process
of marina proposals to assist developers
before they enter the long State and
Federal permit review process.

3) Produce a Boater’s Guide to Baltimore
Harbor to give boaters information on
available facilities and special opera-

= ‘ : tional requirements. This became avail-

. — able in the summer of 1982. Over 5,000

copies have been distributed.

The Task force has also recommended
that the City work with recreational boaters
N and the shipping community to undertake a
. - study to:



Marina in the Middle Branc 1) Identify the best locations for marinas
in the harbor which will not conflict
with commercial shipping.

2) Determine the requirements and pos-
sible impacts of the marina sites rela-
tive to parking needed and the types of
services which should be provided.

3) Determine the location of public boat-
ing ramps to meet the growing
demand in the harbor.

4) Determine the amount and sources of
funding required for development of
public facilities.





5) Coordinate, expand and publicize edu-
cational programs for the boating
public.

The City should also work with State
agencies to identify sites and construct boat
launches supported by the State’s Waterway
Improvement Fund, which has been a major
resource for the construction of boating
facilities in*Maryland. The increasing popu-
larity of the harbor for boating and the as
yet unmet demand for marinas and public
boat launches warrant continued State
funding for projects on the Baltimore
waterfront.





Launching a boat at Fort Armistead Park

105
